issue.title: Align the way Hono encode the body section of AMQP messages
issue.body:
While looking into #765 I found out that Hono in most cases uses Data sections:

~~~java
msg.setBody(new Data(new Binary(payload)));
~~~

Sometimes AmqpValues of type `byte[]`:

~~~java
request.setBody(new AmqpValue(payload.getBytes()));
~~~

Sometimes AmqpValues of type String:

~~~java
message.setContentType(CONTENT_TYPE_APPLICATION_JSON);
message.setBody(new AmqpValue(payload.encode()));
~~~

I think this should be aligned to use the same way in every case. Preferably using data sections.

body: So is there an agreement that we will do that? In that case I would suggest we fix the remaining parts for 0.7, as #765 shows this has a significant performance impact.

@ctron I appreciate your enthusiasm for improving things all over the place. However, we already have enough on our plate for 0.7 (see project board https://github.com/eclipse/hono/projects/7). I would really appreciate, if we could focus on getting the stuff done that we already scheduled for 0.7 instead of adding more and more stuff. I have no problem discussing this issue *after* 0.7 is released and we find some time to think about what should be in 0.8 ...
I simply think that the performance improvements may be significant. But ok, let's move this past 0.7.

So, FMPOV there are two things we need to (re-)consider
1. The AMQP 1.0 spec (section 3.2.4) seems to advise to *only* set the content type to *opaque/binary* if the payload is explicitly known to contain *truly opaque* data,  i.e. if we know that the type of the data will be irrelevant to the consumer (my interpretation). 
2. The spec advises (*SHOULD NOT*) to *not* set a content type if the payload is *not* contained in a *Data* section.

The former should be addressed by another issue. Regarding the latter, we need to consider
* that this would constitute a breaking change of the Credentials, Tenant and Device Registration APIs
* that we want to allow those APIs to be implemented using a JMS provider, which has some implications regarding the supported message properties and payload types

Digging a little deeper into the AMQP-JMS Mapping specification, it seems that a JMS provider is required to map a String valued AMQP Value into a JMS TextMessage (that's what we rely on today). It is also required to map a Data section to a TextMessage, if it contains one of the *well known* content types indicating a text message. *application/json* is one of those content types. So, my understanding is that if we want to change the API then we should do both change the section's type from *AMQP Value* to *Data* and require the content-type to be set to *application/json*.

> … then we should do both change the section's type from *AMQP Value* to *Data* and require the content-type to be set to *application/json*.

I just checked a little bit into the different code paths which lead to a call, setting the payload. Setting the content type is easy. *Requiring* this is a different story. However I would like to actually enforce this.

Just looking a the request/response clients for a moment. All of the inherit from `AbstractRequestResponseClient`, and this class provides a huge amount of `createAndSendRequest` methods. Some of them accepting a content type, some not. All of them accepting a `Buffer` as payload.

Now if we simply ignore backward compatibility for a moment, I think it would make sense to drop all of them, in favor of a single (or two) methods accepting a `JsonObject` as payload, and accepting no "content type" at all.

---

We could get to this, by simply deprecating `AbstractRequestResponseClient` and creating a new `AbstractJsonRequestResponseClient`, which would be a cleaned up copy of the current `AbstractRequestResponseClient`. This way, should someone rely on the `AbstractRequestResponseClient` class, we would still support that. But all client implementations provided by Hono use the new way. Of course if someone would expect that actual client implementations are based on `AbstractRequestResponseClient`, then this would be a problem. But from what I've seen this current interfaces don't leak that inheritance.

Another way would be, but this would break the current way of doing things a bit, to not inherit from `AbstractRequestResponseClient`, but let the actual implementations of the various clients simply use some kind of `JsonRequestResponseClient`. This would still keep the current (non-implementation) class hierarchy, but stop leaking internal APIs in the future.

>  *Requiring* this is a different story. However I would like to actually enforce this.

FMPOV there is no need to require it at the `AbstractRequestResponseClient` level. The concrete subclasses set the content type (if necessary) in their invocation of *createAndSendRequest* and that's it.

There is also no need to drop or modify the existing methods of `AbstractRequestResponseClient`. In fact, we use `Buffer` for the payload because we also want to be able to use this class for sending binary payload (e.g. from the CommandClient).

FMPOV all we need to do is modify the subclasses to explicitly set the content type and modify the *createAndSendRequest* method to use a *Data* section instead of an *AMQP Value* for the payload.

However, the most important thing is to first check, whether e.g. the Qpid JMS provider reads a request message that contains a Data section and an *application/json* content type into a JMS TextMessage ...

> However, the most important thing is to first check, whether e.g. the Qpid JMS provider reads a request message that contains a Data section and an application/json content type into a JMS TextMessage ...

Yes, I will look into that.

We definitely can find way to make that possible for the `CommandClient`… the problem I see with this approach is that we run again into problems, as with the `send` methods. We have a bunch of offered functionality, which in fact is not supported.

> We have a bunch of offered functionality, which in fact is not supported.

Why do you think it is not supported?

> > We have a bunch of offered functionality, which in fact is not supported.
>
> Why do you think it is not supported?

My understanding is that we must put in `application/json`, otherwise it will not work as expected. Yet we do offer a first class citizen method to put in other values.

Only the clients for Tenant, Credentials and Device Registration need to do that. However, since `AbstractRequestResponseClient` is an abstract base class to be used for all kinds of request/response based APIs, it seems reasonable to provide means for setting a content type explicitly. In particular, the CommandClient may set a command specific content type that describes the command's input parameters (payload).

So 3 out of 4 implementations don't need that functionality and it might break when people actually use that.

Which brings me back to my proposal of creating a new abstract base class, with only the necessary functionality. This can be done outside of this PR, to keep it simpler. We can still keep the more complex abstract base, adding everything necessary for the command client.

Feel free to create a new issue for your future refactoring plans. However, I would appreciate it if we could focus on the (rather simple) modifications necessary for fixing this issue for the time being.
